thread.title_full: Bwin.party to Work With GVC on 110-Pence-a-Share Buyout Bid - Bloomberg Business

author: Phil Serafino
title: Bwin.party to Work With GVC on 110-Pence-a-Share Buyout Bid
text:
The battle to buy Bwin.party Digital Entertainment Plc moved a step closer to resolution as the online gambling company said it will work towards securing a 906.5 million-pound ($1.4 billion) bid from GVC Holdings Plc.
GVC, the Isle of Man-based company which has teamed up with Amaya Gaming Group Inc. of Canada, said Thursday it’s made a cash-and-share proposal to acquire Bwin.party for 110 pence a share, countering an overture by competitor 888 Holdings Plc.
The tussle is part of a series of deals in the online gaming industry as companies seek to dominate the market. Amaya last year bought PokerStars for $4.9 billion, while GVC teamed with William Hill Plc to take over Sportingbet Plc in 2013. Bwin.party Chief Executive Officer Norbert Teufelberger has been considering a sale since at least November, when the company said it was in early talks with several parties.
“Based on our experience with the successful Sportingbet acquisition and restructuring, we believe that the potential combination of GVC and bwin.party would result in substantial financial and operating synergies and represent an excellent opportunity for both GVC and bwin.party shareholders,” GVC CEO Kenneth Alexander said in a statement.
Bwin.party said it will work with GVC so that the bidder can finalize the offer in the coming days.
The bid price is 11 percent above Bwin.party’s Wednesday closing price of 99.1 pence. The shares rose 1.2 percent to 100.3 pence as of 8:01 a.m. in London.
There’s no guarantee there will be a formal announcement of a transaction, GVC and Bwin.party said. GVC said May 15 it had submitted a proposal to buy Bwin.party, and four days later it said Amaya, based in Point-Claire, Quebec, would help finance the bid. 888 said last month that its proposal to buy Bwin.party includes cash and shares. It didn’t specify the price.
